summary: Control a social media algorithm and balance truth, attention, and polarization.
description:
You control a social media algorithm. For each turn, decide which posts to boost and which to bury as citizens scroll their feeds.

Problem: We blindly trust feeds that are optimized for profit, not truth.
Key Learning: Algorithms naturally prioritize emotional content, especially anger, because it drives engagement more than nuanced facts.
Outcome: Players practice spotting 'rage-bait' and engagement traps.
Need: Citizens need to understand how their attention is monetized and weaponized.
Goal: Maintain high Public Info (>60%) while keeping Polarization low (<40%) before the turns run out.
title: The Civic Feed

summary: Negotiate with rival parties to assemble a governing majority in a fractured parliament.
description:
You are tasked with building a governing coalition in a fractured parliament. Negotiate with 4 rival political parties to secure enough seats to govern.

Problem: Voters often struggle to understand messy post-election compromises and alliances.
Key Learning: Ideological purity often dies in coalition math; power requires trade-offs.
Outcome: Players grasp government instability and why alliances shift.
Need: Demystifying why politicians make seemingly contradictory alliances after elections.
Goal: Secure 251+ seats (votes) and pass 5 Laws within 10 Weeks without running out of Political Capital.
title: Coalition Builder

summary: Run the 9 PM news and juggle scandals vs. policy while keeping ratings and civic duty alive.
description:
You control a 9 PM news bulletin. Each round, you have 15 seconds to pick stories (Scandals vs Policy) to fill 5 broadcast slots.

Problem: Media businesses rely on capturing attention to survive, often at the cost of quality.
Key Learning: The attention economy pushes sensationalism over substance.
Outcome: Players learn to critically consume headlines and question why certain stories are chosen.
Need: Understanding the commercial pressures behind editorial choices.
Goal: Keep both Ratings (Profit) and Civic Info (Duty) above zero for 5 full hours (rounds).
title: The News Desk

summary: Allocate a strained city budget under pressure from angry sectors and tempting bribes.
description:
You are in charge of a city budget. You have â‚¹100 Cr but the city demands â‚¹160 Cr across 5 angry sectors (Roads, Schools, Health, Housing, etc.).

Problem: Citizens demand world-class services but often ignore fiscal limits.
Key Learning: Budgeting is a zero-sum game; every 'Yes' to one sector forces a 'No' to another.
Outcome: Players understand policy trade-offs and populist pressure on representatives.
Need: Realizing that 'efficiency' isn't magic; resources are finite sand require hard choices.
Goal: Achieve a Re-election Approval rating of 60%+ without being exposed for corruption (if you took bribes).
title: Budget Battle

summary: Seed and track rumors through a network to tilt an election using limited influence.
description:
You operate a whisper campaign during an election. Map how rumors spread through a network and choose which groups (nodes) to target.

Problem: Disinformation thrives in insulated echo chambers where facts cannot penetrate.
Key Learning: Information bubbles insulate voters from reality and can be engineered.
Outcome: Players develop inoculation against network-based propaganda.
Need: Recognizing that misinformation is often designed to exploit social fault lines.
Goal: Flip District Support to 60%+ (or higher for Dictatorship mode) within 14 Days using limited Influence.
title: The Whisper Campaign
